title: 115_hr4865
content: The "Crop Insurance Modernization Act of 2018" may be cited as the short title for this Act. Amendments to the Federal Crop Insurance Act are included in this legislation. Amendments to the Federal Crop Insurance Act include redefining a beginning farmer or rancher and adding a nonvoting ex officio member to the management of a corporation. Amendments to the Federal Crop Insurance Act include expanding the collection and sharing of information related to natural resources and understanding the impact of soil type, soil quality, and conservation practices on risk rating. Additionally, cover crop termination regulations are updated. Amendments to the Insurance Act include requirements for producers to follow good farming practices, including sustainable and organic farming practices, and approved conservation activities. Safe harbor provisions are also defined, including the definition of 'cover crop'. The term 'cover crop termination' refers to a practice that results in the targeted cover crop being terminated. Good farming practices include conservation activities like cover crop management, termination, and agronomic management recognized by the Natural Resources Conservation Service. The Resources Conservation Service will establish an ombudsperson in the Corporation to assist producers with understanding claim denials, rights in denied claims, obtain rule clarifications, and perform other duties as determined by the Secretary. The Federal Crop Insurance Act is amended to include a new subparagraph for research and development activities aimed at developing a paperwork reduction policy for operations with less than $1,000,000 in revenue. This policy will streamline the purchase and approval process to the maximum extent possible. The Federal Crop Insurance Act is amended to include a new subparagraph for research and development activities aimed at developing a paperwork reduction policy for operations with less than $1,000,000 in revenue. This policy will streamline the approval process while maintaining actuarial soundness. Additionally, reports on beginning farmer barriers and expansion of revenue policy availability are required to be submitted to the relevant committees. The Federal Crop Insurance Act requires the Corporation to submit an annual report to the Committees on Agriculture regarding the 10 most widely grown crops without revenue policies and the feasibility of developing revenue policies for them. Additionally, a Conservation Practice-Based Pilot Program is added to the Act. The Federal Crop Insurance Act mandates an annual report on widely grown crops and feasibility of revenue policies. A Conservation Practice-Based Pilot Program offers premium subsidies to eligible producers in up to 6 states with high loss ratios, expiring no earlier than 5 years after enactment. A report on yield records and conservation success is required 1 year after enactment. The subsection defines an "eligible producer" as someone in a high loss county who practices conservation techniques for at least 5 years after the enactment of the program. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO FOOD SECURITY ACT OF 1985. The Food Security Act of 1985 is amended to include annual spot checks on farms for compliance with conservation plans. Additionally, modifications for ephemeral gullies are required for producers with existing conservation plans. The Food Security Act of 1985 now includes annual spot checks on farms for compliance with conservation plans. Producers must modify their plans to include treatment for ephemeral gullies, and must implement the revised plan within 1 year. Producers are prohibited from allowing ephemeral gullies to become classic gullies to avoid treatment. The Corporation cannot use production records from one parcel of land to establish production history on another parcel.
